content:
Magic (marvelous object) given back to placate crying
child.

child: Stolen magic object stolen back by helpful animals.
Stolen magic object stolen back by helpful cat and dog.
Magic object recovered with lioness‘s help.

Recovered magic articles dropped by rescuing animals into
the sea.
Magic object stolen back by servant.
Stolen magic object stolen back by man in disguise.

content: Magic object recovered by using second magic object.

*Type 561; *Aarne MSFO XXV 3--83; *BP II 547ff.--Jewish:
Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 24.
child: Recovery of magic object by use of magic apples.

These apples cause horns
to grow. (Cf. †D895.) *Type 566; BP I 470ff; Aarne MSFO XXV 85--97.
Recovery of magic object by use of magic cudgel.
Recovery of magic object cures madness.

content: Magic object recovered through recitation of magic formula.
Magic object recovered with devil’s help.
child: Magic object recovered with witch‘s help.

content: Thief forced to vomit up stolen magic object.

child: Magic object disappears at owner‘s death.
Magic object destroyed because of feigned sickness.

content:
Magic objects acquired by acting as umpire for fighting
heirs.

When hero gets hold of objects he refuses to return it.--*Types 400, 518; *BP
II 331ff.; Cosquin Indiens 371ff.; Saintyves Perrault 287ff.; Hdwb. d. Märchens
I 97.--Icelandic: Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesian: DeVries
Volksverhalen No. 104; Chinese: Chavannes 500 Contes III 259 No. 470; Africa:
Frobenius Atlantis II 113, 175, III 336, IV 110.

child: Magic object acquired as reward for vigil.
Magic object acquired as reward for religious austerities.
Magic object acquired as reward for quest into grave.
Magic object as reward for faith.
Magic object as reward for good deeds.

content: Magic object acquired by gaining love of owner.

(No trick).--Hartland Perseus III 200; Irish myth: Cross;
N. A. Indian (Ponca, Ojibwa, European borrowings): Thompson CColl II 329f.
Magic object voluntarily restored to giver.
child: Magic sword returned to lake whence it was received.
Magic sword thrown into lake by dying hero.

content: Magic object forged by smith to order.

(Goose that laid the golden egg). Greek fable: Wienert FFC
LVI 64 (ET 283), 106 (ST 182); Babrius 123; Halm Aesop No. 343.--India: Keith
145 (gold-producing boy), Thompson-Balys; Panchatantra III 6 (tr. Ryder) 331;
Cowell Jataka I 292 No. 136; Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesian: Dixon 238 n. 51; N.
A. Indian: *Thompson-Tales 306 n. 109z.
Magic object loses power by overuse.

*Chauvin V 11 No. 7; India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Eberhard FFC CXX 106, 109.--Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 248 No. 24.
child: Magic wishing-ring loses power by touching water.

Extraordinary flower preserves its freshness so long as it
remains unperceived by anyone other than owner.
Magic object taken from ogre‘s house.

Hartland Perseus III 201; Icelandic: *Boberg; Japanese:
Ikeda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Magic object stolen in Thor’s temple.
Magic object taken in the serpents‘ country.
Magic armor stolen from dwarf by giant.
Magic helmet taken directly from bystander.

Boy overhears witches’ conversation about magic objects,
which he gets possession of.

Prince procures magic object from bathing fairy when he
steals her clothes.

Man poisons couple, owners of magic gong, and gains
possession of it.
Magic object taken from dead enemy.

Magic root acquired by tricking mother bird into searching
for it in order to disentangle her young.
Fairy dun acquired by tricking owner.
Magic object acquired by rapping on tree.
Quest to hell for magic object.
Aarne FFC XXIII 130, JSFO XXVII 48.--Icelandic: Boberg.
Magic object received from other world.

Magic object obtained by reaching in certain cardinal
direction.

N. A. Indian: *Kroeber JAFL XXI
224, (California): Gayton and Newman 75.

Scottish: Campbell-McKay No. 15; Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo
II 33.

Magic object to be chosen from among identical worthless
objects.

Insect helps in choice. East
Africa: Torrend Zs. f. afrikan. u. ozean. Spr. I 247ff.

Magic object obtained as compensation for loss of entire
herd--the spirit of the herd resides in the last goat‘s tail, which old woman
keeps.
Magic object left by frightened demons.
Magic object as ransom of captive.

Foolish brother (wife)
exchanges old object for new. *Type 561; *BP II 205.--Breton: Sébillot
Incidents s.v. “bague”; India: Thompson-Balys.

Exchange of common cow for gold-dropping cow made by
daughter when her father stops at her home for the night.

content: Magic object received from God (a god).

*Toldo IX 451ff.--Irish
myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Örvar-Odds saga 138--41, Boberg; Finnish: Kalevala
rune 36; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “baguette”;
Greek: Fox 40, *Grote I 88.
child: Magic object falls down from the heaven.

Magic needle and thread fall from heaven as result of
prayer.

content: Magic object received from supernatural being.
child:
BP I 361.--Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; French
Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 15f.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC
CXX 25, 50.

*Aarne MSFO XXV
39.--Irish myth: Cross; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “baguette”; Hindu: Penzer IX 45 n. 1.

*Aarne MSFO XXV 39; *Chauvin V 78 No. 22 n. 1.--Icelandic:
*Boberg; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 25; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 47, 211.
Magic object received from the dead in lower world.
Magic object acquired as reward for burial of the dead.
Magic object received from temple demons.
Magic object received from witch or wizard.
Magic object received from dragon king.
Magic object received from lady in dream.

(Cf. †D825.)--Hdwb. d.
Märchens s.v. “Baum”; BP II 544.--Irish myth:
Cross; Greek: Fox 40; India: Thompson-Balys.
Magic object received from giantess in dream.
Magic object received from man in dream.
Magic object received from wild man.
Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.
Angel reveals location of magic object.
Magic sword received from dwarf in dream.

India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 849,
II 210, 656.

content:
*Type 510.--Irish myth:
*Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “baguette”; Missouri French: Carrière.
child: Magic sword received from Lady of Lake.

(Cf. †D878.1.)--Irish
myth: *Cross; English: Wells 50 (Le Morte Arthur); Indo-Chinese: Scott
Indo-Chinese 303.
Magic cauldron received from lake spirit.
Magic object received from grateful fairy.

Hero has cured sick fairy by making her laugh. English:
Baughman; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Magic object received from maiden in otherworld island.

content: Magic objects received from sun, moon, and stars, etc.

child:
(Cf. †D842.)--*Type 510;
Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 301, Boberg; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 145.

Hartland Perseus III 199.--Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic:
MacCulloch Eddic 308 (Tyrfing), *Boberg.

Breton: Sébillot
Incidents s.v. “baguette”; Missouri French:
Carrière.
Magic object received from girl‘s foster-mother.

content: Magic object received from grateful person.

*Type 560; *Aarne MSFO
XXV 40; BP II 39.--Icelandic: *Boberg; Missouri French: Carrière; N. A. Indian
(Malecite, Penobscot): Thompson CColl II 411ff. (European borrowings).
child:
Magic object received from man in return for rescue of
child.

Magic object received from dwarf in return for rescue of
child or kindness to child.

Magic object received from grateful father of redeemed
snake.
Magic object received in return for being shaved.

content:
Magic object returned in payment for removal of magic
horns.
Magic object acquired by tricking giant.

Giant is persuaded to
give the objects to the hero. (Cf. †D831, where the person tricked is often a
giant.)--Type 328.

child: Attempt to learn about magic object by spying.

content: Magic object acquired by trick exchange.

By means of second magic
object hero recovers first. (Often mixed with †D832).--*Types 302, 400, 507,
569; BP I 464; Penzer I 25ff.--India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesian: DeVries
Volksverhalen Nos. 3, 104.
Magic object acquired by exchanging letters.
Magic object received from old man.
Magic object acquired through foolish bargain.

Type 590.--N. A. Indian (Micmac) (European borrowing):
Thompson CColl II 412.
Magic object found in magic castle.
child: Golden cot found in magic castle.

content: Magic object found in underground room.
child: Magic object found in giant’s cave.

content: Magic object acquired by tricking devil.

Man gets shelter in
storm; devil gets wet. Devil gives man magic object in return for information
as to how he kept dry.--Köhler-Bolte I 416.

German: Grimm No. 122; Chinese-Persian: *Coyajee JPASB
XXIV 197.

Fansler MAFLS XII 17; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; Jewish: Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Georgia Negro: Harris Nights
30; S. A. Indian (Toba): Métraux MAFLS XL 130.
child: Magic object stolen from local deity.
Magic object stolen by host (at inn.)

*Type 563; *BP I 349ff.;
**Aarne JSFO XXVII 1--96.--Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “aubergiste”; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 24; Missouri French:
Carrière; India: Thompson-Balys; Seneca: Curtin-Hewitt RBAE XXXII 264 No. 50
(not at inn).

**Aarne JSFO XXVII 1--96, especially 48; *BP I 349ff.;
Type 564.--India: Thompson-Balys.
Magic object stolen by rival for wife.
Magic object stolen by rival‘s emissary.
Magic object stolen by hero’s wife.
Magic object stolen in card game.
Magic object carried off by bird.
Magic horn carried off by bird.

Magic objects stolen from owner by his daughter, with whom
he spends the night.
Magic object carried away; child allowed to play with it.
Death to follow loss of magic object.
Loss of magic object causes madness.

content: Magic object taken away by force.
Magic jewel carried off by bird.

This happens when the
jewel is examined by daylight. (Cf. †D861.7.)--*Chauvin V 211 No. 120; *Gerould
PMLA XIX 392ff.; Krappe Neophilologus XIV 90; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child: Magic ring carried off by bird.
Magic object pointed out by bird.
Magic object found on an island.
Magic object found in a wood.
Magic object found in heart of whale.
Magic object found under dead girl’s tongue.
Magic object pointed out by divine voice.
Magic object found on mother‘s grave.
Magic object found on father‘s grave.
Magic object found on grave of slain helpful animal.

Cox 477; Saintyves
Perrault 37; Hdwb. d. Märchens s.v. “Baum”.--Japanese:
Ikeda.
Magic object received by apprentice from master.

content:
Hartland Perseus III 199.--Icelandic: *Boberg; Irish myth:
Cross.
child:
Magic object received from cat-woman; i.e. woman transformed
intermittently to cat.

--French: Cosquin
No. 11; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 400f.

content: Magic object received through particular intermediaries.

Only one person can help secure it.--*Chauvin V 59 No. 19
n. 1.

child: Magic object vomited by conquered monster.

content: Magic object received from old woman.

Hartland Perseus III
199.--Italian Novella: Rotunda; Missouri French: Carrière; Cape Verde Islands:
Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 123.

Magic object acquired through trickery: child forced to cry
till object is given.

Icelandic: Egils
saga ok Asm., ch. XIV 10, Boberg.

child: Magic object received from green-clad huntsman.

content: Magic object returns to original place.
child: Magic mango returns to tree for broken tabu.
Magic objects created by God on sixth day.
Magic objects possessed by witch, sorcerer or evil dwarf.

content:
Magic object effective only when exact instructions for its
use are followed.
child: Magic object effective when struck on ground once only.

Second blow renders useless. Africa (Bulu): Krug JAFL XXV
113 No. 9.

Magic charm (formula) used injudiciously brings death to
owner’s wife, children, himself.

content: Magic object to be used only in extreme need.
Ineffable name written on object renders it magic.
